The '''Wainriders''' were a people, or confederacy of [[Men]] from the [[East]].<ref name="Gondor">{{App|Gondor}}, entry for King Narmacil II, p. 1048</ref>

They traveled in great wagons (wains) and their chieftains rode [[chariots]] in battle. In addition, they were better armed and stronger than previous [[Easterlings|invaders from the East]].<ref name="Gondor" /> They camped in fortified camps of wagons. Their young women were also trained in arms, and they, along with old men and youths, stayed behind, able to defend their homes from attackers.<ref>{{UT|Northmen}}, seventh paragraph</ref>

The Wainriders were stirred by [[Sauron]] to descend upon [[Gondor]] and its allies, some two centuries after the time of the [[Great Plague]]<ref>{{App|TA}}, entry for the year 1636, p. 1086</ref> and remained a dire threat for nearly a hundred years.

==History== 
The Wainriders entered history in {{TA|1851}} during the reign of King [[Narmacil II]] of [[Gondor]]<ref>{{App|South}}, ''Kings of Gondor'', date of death following the name of Telumehtar Umbardacil, p. 1038</ref> when they began their attack on [[Gondor]].<ref>{{App|TA}}, entry for the year 1851, p. 1086</ref> They quickly overran and scattered the [[Northmen]],<ref name="fourth">{{UT|Northmen}}, fourth paragraph</ref> who were living in the plains between the forest of [[Mirkwood]] and the [[River Running]] with permanent homes on the eaves of the forest, especially in the [[East Bight]].<ref>{{UT|Northmen}}, second paragraph</ref>

In {{TA|1856}}<ref name="Gondor" /> King Narmacil went north to the plains south of Mirkwood with a large army and assembled as many of the scattered remnants of the Northmen as he was able to. The Wainriders defeated the army of Gondor and the Northmen and killed King Narmacil in the [[Battle of the Plains]]. The defeated army of Gondor retreated over the [[Dagorlad]] to Ithilien. Gondor had to retreat its borders to the Anduin and the [[Emyn Muil]]<ref name="Gondor" /> and abandoned all its possessions east<ref>{{App|TA}}, entry for the year 1856, p. 1086</ref> of the [[Anduin]] except [[Ithilien]].<ref name="fourth" /> It is believed that the [[Nazgûl|Ringwraiths]] entered [[Mordor]] at this time.<ref name="Gondor" /> The Wainriders occupied the lands of the Northmen and enslaved most of the survivors who stayed behind; a few Northmen fled over the River Running and joined the people of [[Dale]] near the [[Lonely Mountain]], others to Gondor and some followed [[Marhwini]] to the [[Vales of Anduin]].<ref>{{UT|Northmen}}, fifth paragraph</ref>

The enslaved Northmen revolted against the Wainriders, and Narmacil's son [[Calimehtar (King of Gondor)|Calimehtar]] took advantage; in {{TA|1899|n}}<ref>{{App|TA}}, entry for the year 1899, p. 1086</ref> he defeated the Wainriders on the plain of [[Dagorlad]] winning a temporary reprieve.<ref>{{App|Gondor}}, entry for King Calimehtar, p. 1048</ref>

After that defeat, the Wainriders allied themselves with the [[Haradrim|Men]] of [[Near Harad]] and [[Khand]] and made a simultaneous assault on Gondor from the north and the south. In {{TA|1944}}<ref>{{App|TA}}, entry for the year 1944, p. 1086</ref> King [[Ondoher]] was lost in the [[Disaster of the Morannon|northern battle]], but his general [[Eärnil II|Eärnil]] defeated the southern invaders. The victorious Wainrider army in the north, celebrating their victory over Ondoher, suddenly found themselves set upon by Eärnil. In an encounter that became known as the [[Battle of the Camp]], the Wainriders were put to rout out of Ithilien, and a great part of those who fled perished in the [[Dead Marshes]].<ref>{{App|Gondor}}, entry for King Ondoher, p. 1049</ref>

It was later seen that the invasions of the Wainriders, as so many of Gondor's perils, were engineered by the emissaries of Sauron.<ref name="Gondor" />

==Inspiration==
Miryam Librán-Moreno compares the Wainriders with the [[Wikipedia:Huns|Huns]] and states that the Huns were a nomadic people from Central Asia who rode in chariots providing chapter 40 (i.e. XL in roman numbers) paragraph 210 of Jordanes' ''De origine actibusque Getarum'' (abbreviated as ''Get.'' by her) as a reference for the latter statement. She also mentions that the Huns invaded the steppes north of the [[Wikipedia:Black Sea|Black Sea]] and defeated and enslaved the [[Wikipedia:Goths|Goths]] who lived there.<ref>Miryam Librán-Moreno, "'Byzantium, New Rome!': Goths, Langobards, and Byzantium in ''The Lord of the Rings''", in ''[[Tolkien and the Study of His Sources]]'' (edited by [[Jason Fisher]], p. 99</ref> [[Wikipedia:Jordanes|Jordanes]] was an Eastern Roman writer from the sixth century who is believed to be of Gothic descent who wrote about the History of the Goths in latin. However, Jordanes only mentioned that [[Wikipedia:Attila the Hun|Attila the Hun]] had the camp to which he fled during the [[Wikipedia:Battle of the Catalaunian Plains|Battle of the Catalaunian Planes]] fortified with wagons and also mentioned that the Huns fought together with various other allied peoples, including the [[Wikipedia:Amali dynasty|Ostrogoths]] and the [[Wikipedia:Gepids|Gepidae]].<ref>{{webcite|website=Internet Archive|author=Charles Cristopher Mierow|articlename=The Gothic History of Jordanes|articleurl=http://ia800303.us.archive.org/1/items/gothichistoryofj00jord/gothichistoryofj00jord.pdf}}</ref> [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] was familiar with [[Gothic]]<ref name="L272">{{L|272}}</ref> and latin<ref>{{L|163}}</ref><ref>{{L|294}}</ref> and the history of the Goths.<ref name="L272" /><ref>{{L|43}}</ref> He also mentioned that the name [[Mirkwood]] (in very early German ''mirkiwidu'') was used for the boundary between the Goths and the Huns<ref>{{L|289}}</ref> and used latinized Gothic names for persons from the early [[Northmen]] of [[Rhovanion]], such as [[Vidugavia]] and [[Vidumavi]].<ref>{{UT|8e}}, note 6</ref>

[[Andreas Moehn]] notes that some ancient peoples traveled in wagons, such as the ''[[Wikipedia:Hamaxobii|Hamaxobioi]]'' from Greek sources, or the ''[[Wikipedia:Scythians|Scythians]]''.<ref>{{webcite|website=Lalaith|author=[[Andreas Moehn]]|articlename=The Men of Darkness|articleurl=http://lalaith.vpsurf.de/Tolkien/Men_of_Darkness.html}} [''Amaxoluoi'' is an error].</ref>
